Gangsa is a single-handheld smooth-surfaced metal gong with a narrow rim. The circular, bronze gong is classified as a struck idiophone in the Sachs-Hornbostel System. An ensemble of gangsa usually consists of six(6) gongs which vary in size such that the largest gong and the smallest gong have the lowest and highest pitch, respectively. It is played by using two techniques - toppaya which involves the use of bare hands in beating and is done in a half kneeling position with the gongs placed on the laps of men playing them; and palook or pattung which involves the use of a wooden mallet, or a stick. The gong can be played using several styles such as damping, sliding of the palm, or simply letting it ring. Regarded as one of the most sacred instruments in the Cordillera region in the Philippines, they provide rhythm and music to the dances performed in rituals, feasts, and other cultural gatherings. 

			This Android mobile application is part of an undergraduate research project of students from the University of the Philippines Diliman. It aims to demonstrate different playing styles of gangsa using gestures and corresponding digitally synthesized sounds of said instrument.
